newsitem.title: USA: Computer hacker charged with credit card theft in U.S.
newsitem.headline: Computer hacker charged with credit card theft in U.S.

text.p: The FBI Thursday charged a computer hacker with the theft of more than 100,000 credit card numbers from a database on the Internet.
Carlos Felipe Salgado, 36, was arrested after he tried to sell the information to an undercover agent. He faces a 15 year prison term and $500,000 in fines if convicted.

An FBI spokesman said agents were tipped off by computer technicians for an internet service provider who observed unusual activity while working on the system's servers. Around the same time, the FBI learned of a scheme by Salgado to sell thousands of account numbers.

Undercover agents made two small purchases from Salgado and then arranged to meet him at the San Franciso International Airport and pay $260,000 for 100,000 credit card numbers. Shortly after that transaction, agents arrested Salgado at his parents home in Daly City, Calif.
Salgado used the online name "Smak" and appears to have obtained his information with a computer program that gathered credit information from companies selling products over the Internet.
